href="/our-people/tamara-gruenewald" class="mdc-c-link-inline___7DRrt_990311c mdc-c-link-inline--secondary___YKoOK_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Tamara Gr√ºenewald</span></a><br><span> with </span><span>Muthu Subbu</span></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-8 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11 ArticleContent_mck-c-article-content__share-tools__kWRRw"></div></section><section class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 mck-u-animation-blur-in-400"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"><div class="mck-u-links-inline">New analysis suggests that much of Europe‚Äôs anticipated electricity demand growth may not materialize, with important implications for the energy transition and industrial competitiveness.</div></div></div></section><main data-layer-region="article-body" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xxl"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-1 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap">
<p><strong>Rising uncertainty surrounding future electricity demand</strong> could affect Europe‚Äôs energy transition and power infrastructure investment plans. Governments and system operators have projected that power demand in major European countries could increase by as much as 7 percent per year to 2030 after two decades of relative stagnation. In McKinsey‚Äôs <em><a href="/industries/energy-and-materials/our-insights/global-energy-perspective">Global Energy Perspective 2024</a></em> report, the Continued Momentum scenario projects growth to be only slightly above 2 percent CAGR.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8ca67f3f-df95-4c4f-a38e-a0172220f3ca"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8ca67f3f-df95-4c4f-a38e-a0172220f3ca" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em><a href="/industries/energy-and-materials/our-insights/global-energy-perspective">Global Energy Perspective 2024</a></em>, McKinsey, September 17, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> Further McKinsey analysis has found that up to 40 percent of this modeled growth may not, in fact, materialize. The possible impact of this reduced demand outlook might be profound if higher system costs drive up the price of electricity and potentially accelerate deindustrialization in the region.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Our analysis</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>We have assessed the level of European electrification that could be at risk in the Continued Momentum scenario of McKinsey‚Äôs <em>Global Energy Perspective 2024,</em> given current progress across demand drivers, including heat pumps, electric vehicle (EV) penetration, and regulation, and forecasts for the electrification of industrial processes. This analysis takes into account recent sales numbers (including for EVs and heat pumps), current project status (of electrolyzer plants, for example), and company activities and announcements (including current and planned production volumes or plant closures).</p>
<p>In this article, Europe refers to the European Union plus Norway, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom. There may be some gaps in the data based on availability. Note that in other regions, the situation described in this article may be markedly different‚Äîin many emerging economies, population and GDP growth, as well as increased energy consumption per capita due to a rise in living standards and industrialization, are driving much higher demand forecasts.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="674b7d57-7883-45c8-8252-66e4a061ca9f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="674b7d57-7883-45c8-8252-66e4a061ca9f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em><a href="/industries/energy-and-materials/our-insights/global-energy-perspective">Global Energy Perspective 2024</a></em>, McKinsey, September 17, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span></p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Factors, including elevated power prices, energy efficiency gains, and structural economic changes linked to deindustrialization, may all moderate the expected electricity demand growth. Mario Draghi‚Äôs recent report on the future of European competitiveness warns that the region faces a slow economic decline linked to deindustrialization.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="be3412b1-1f39-42d4-94ce-74d84cb19c06"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="be3412b1-1f39-42d4-94ce-74d84cb19c06" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Mario Draghi, <em>The future of European competitiveness</em>, European Commission, September 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> Our analysis indicates that elevated power prices‚Äîwhich are currently 60 to 90 euros per megawatt hour (EUR/MWh) across Europe versus historical averages of 30 to 50 EUR/MWh‚Äîcould increase industrial production costs and result in lower-than-expected power demand from the industrial sector (see sidebar ‚ÄúOur analysis‚Äù). While reduced industrial demand is the primary contributing factor and focus of this article, shifts in overall industrial activity are, of course, a function of many interconnected factors, including macroeconomic conditions or demographic shifts.</p>
<p>Following the major industrial shutdowns of 2022‚Äì23, several big industrial players have more recently announced plans to move production to lower-cost locations.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="29d299ed-00e6-4133-bebd-29f97c85c266"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="29d299ed-00e6-4133-bebd-29f97c85c266" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Christina Amann and Victoria Waldersee, ‚ÄúVolkswagen considers historic German plant closures in cost drive,‚Äù Reuters, September 3, 2024; Bert Fr√∂ndhoff, ‚ÄúBASF closes two more plants in Germany,‚Äù Handelsblatt, July 11, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> Meanwhile, the uptake of other important electricity demand drivers, such as electric vehicles (EVs) and heat pumps, has slowed in the last three years, adding further questions about how European power demand could evolve in the years to 2030.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="431dd30b-7b1d-49e5-ad8f-f320de5f276a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="431dd30b-7b1d-49e5-ad8f-f320de5f276a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚Äú<a href="/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/our-insights/the-energy-transition-where-are-we-really">The energy transition: Where are we, really?</a>,‚Äù McKinsey, August 27, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>In this article, we examine the expected trajectory of electricity demand in Europe through 2030, the factors that may prevent this from fully materializing, and the broader implications for the region. We also touch on potential solutions such as revised market design, infrastructure build-out, demand-side response, and electrification incentives.</p>
<h2>Why electricity demand is expected to grow</h2>
<p>Power demand has long been expected to grow in Europe as increasing population and rising GDP drive higher overall energy consumption (despite efficiency gains). The current boom in AI could create a further demand surge, with data centers possibly accounting for as much as
<a href="/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/our-insights/the-role-of-power-in-unlocking-the-european-ai-revolution">5 percent of total European power consumption by 2030</a>.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>The evolving energy transition: McKinsey‚Äôs latest analysis</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>
</p>
<p>This article is part of McKinsey‚Äôs recent series of articles taking stock of the energy transition:</p>
<ul>
    <li><a href="/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/our-insights/the-energy-transition-where-are-we-really">‚ÄúThe energy transition: Where are we, really?</a>‚Äù explores the reality gap between current low-carbon technology deployment and what is required to achieve net-zero targets.</li>
    <li><a href="/industries/energy-and-materials/our-insights/global-energy-perspective"><em>Global Energy Perspective 2024</em></a> offers a detailed energy demand outlook for 68 sectors and 78 fuels on a 1.5¬∞ pathway, as set out in the Paris Agreement, as well as three bottom-up energy transition scenarios: the Sustainable Transformation scenario, the Continued Momentum scenario (the base scenario used in this article), and the Slow Evolution scenario. These scenarios have been updated this year to reflect changing global conditions, including geopolitical challenges, increasingly complex supply chains, and higher inflation.</li>
    <li><a href="/industries/energy-and-materials/our-insights/global-materials-perspective"><em>Global Materials Perspective 2024</em></a>, published for the first time this year, provides an in-depth look at the critical materials needed to enable the energy transition and their impact on the materials supply-and-demand landscape.</li>
    <li><a href="/mgi/our-research/the-hard-stuff-navigating-the-physical-realities-of-the-energy-transition"><em>The hard stuff: Navigating the physical realities of the energy transition</em></a> explores the 25 interlinked physical challenges that need to be tackled to advance the energy transition, including developing and deploying new low-emissions technologies and entirely new supply chains and infrastructure to support them.</li>
    <li>‚Äú<a href="/industries/private-capital/our-insights/how-data-centers-and-the-energy-sector-can-sate-ais-hunger-for-power">How data centers and the energy sector can sate AI‚Äôs hunger for power</a>‚Äù delves into the data center and power infrastructure investment potential in the United States as power demand from AI continues to surge.</li>
    <li>‚Äú<a href="/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/our-insights/the-role-of-power-in-unlocking-the-european-ai-revolution">The role of power in unlocking the European AI revolution</a>‚Äù unpacks the booming demand for data centers, driven by technologies such as AI, and how this could impact European power demand.</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Meanwhile, the energy transition has also spurred new transmission and distribution (T&D) investments to accommodate growing demand and the deployment of increasingly dispersed renewable energy sources (see sidebar ‚ÄúThe evolving energy transition: McKinsey‚Äôs latest analysis‚Äù).</p>
<p>The European Union‚Äôs commitment to achieving net zero by 2050 has led to increasingly ambitious policies concerning emissions, renewables, EVs, and heat pumps, all of which point to growing power demand. For example, the REPowerEU initiative aims to have at least 30 million newly installed heat pumps by 2030, up from 22 million in 2023, and the Renewable Energy Directive (RED III) has raised the 2030 target for renewable energy‚Äôs share of final consumption to 42.5 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="db811e6f-9025-468b-8736-441f16578da2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="db811e6f-9025-468b-8736-441f16578da2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚ÄúCommunication from the Commission to the European Parliament, the European Council, the Council, the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions. REPowerEU: Joint European Action for more affordable, secure and sustainable energy,‚Äù European Commission, March 8, 2022; <em>European heat pump market and statistics report 2023</em>, European Heat Pump Association.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Other factors that could cause demand to grow include longer-term policies looking beyond 2030, regulations such as ‚ÄúFit for 55,‚Äù the decreasing costs of electrification technology, and GDP recovery.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7662a668-a488-4121-9284-1a39f07ce9c1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7662a668-a488-4121-9284-1a39f07ce9c1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚ÄúFit for 55: Delivering on the proposals,‚Äù European Council, accessed September 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> Taken together, these growth-signaling factors have led governments and system operators across major economies to forecast a 1 to 7 percent annual increase in electricity demand until 2030 (Exhibit 1).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/electricity%20demand%20in%20europe%20growing%20or%20going/svgz-european-power-demand_ex1-v17.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Governments and system operations remain optimistic about demand growth." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/electricity%20demand%20in%20europe%20growing%20or%20going/svgz-european-power-demand_ex1-v17.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <h2>Factors putting demand growth at risk</h2>
<p>According to our latest analysis, however, these growth expectations may not be attainable. In fact, electricity consumption in Europe has already slowed. Following steady growth of 1.4 percent per annum through the 2000s, peaking in 2008, demand growth has remained relatively muted. Since 2021, demand has dropped consistently at around 3 percent per annum, failing to meet expectations for a post-COVID-19 ‚Äúbounce back‚Äù (Exhibit 2).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/electricity%20demand%20in%20europe%20growing%20or%20going/svgz-european-power-demand_ex2-v17.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Electricity demand has been on a downward trajectory from the 2008 peak, with a three percent yearly decline from 2021." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/electricity%20demand%20in%20europe%20growing%20or%20going/svgz-european-power-demand_ex2-v17.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Historically, electricity demand was closely correlated with economic growth in most European economies‚Äîover 2 percent GDP growth per annum between 2000 and 2008, a correlation of around 0.96 between electricity demand growth and GDP for that period.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e9950c15-2e4e-480f-bbf5-67e721b74e90"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e9950c15-2e4e-480f-bbf5-67e721b74e90" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚ÄúGDP growth (annual %),‚Äù World Bank Group, September 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> But after the financial crisis and growth peak in 2008, GDP and electricity demand have delinked in these countries (with a correlation of approximately ‚Äì0.53).</p>
<p>There are various underlying reasons for the decline in demand growth in recent years:</p>
<ul>
    <li>The COVID-19 pandemic and the invasion of Ukraine both impacted Europe‚Äôs power demand profile. The conflict in Ukraine triggered a gas shortage, with the resulting higher gas prices peaking at a yearly average of around $41 per metric million British thermal unit (MMBTU) in 2022‚Äîup from a yearly average of $6/MMBTU in 2017 to 2019.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="36308c92-057c-49c1-a619-03742696c363"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="36308c92-057c-49c1-a619-03742696c363" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚ÄúCrude oil and natural gas,‚Äù Bloomberg, accessed October 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> This, along with operational challenges at reduced-output nuclear plants in France and low hydroelectric production, caused many industrial companies to shut down across sectors such as steel, aluminum, and chemicals.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="91e5bc58-36b7-4c7d-b9b4-f32558f9bd8b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="91e5bc58-36b7-4c7d-b9b4-f32558f9bd8b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Electricity 2024,</em> International Energy Agency, May 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> This deindustrialization trend has had a significant impact on power demand and is one of the key reasons why growth remains below historical levels.</li>
    <li>The drop in power demand is also driven by considerable energy efficiency gains, structural economic changes‚Äîsuch as offshoring and the transition to a more services-oriented economy‚Äîand milder winters over the past couple of years that have reduced the demand for space heating.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="861f6bfd-06a8-49bb-b091-0f8459c63165"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="861f6bfd-06a8-49bb-b091-0f8459c63165" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚ÄúClimate reanalysis,‚Äù European Commission, Opernicus, Implemented by ECMWF, and Climate Change Service, September 2024; ‚ÄúNyrstar to suspend Budel zinc operations in second half of January,‚Äù Reuters, January 15, 2024; Rachel Morison and Aine Quinn, ‚ÄúHigh gas prices force UK fertilizer plant to shut down,‚Äù Bloomberg, June 2, 2022; and ‚ÄúGermany‚Äôs Speira to end Rheinwerk aluminium smelting due to energy costs,‚Äù Reuters, March 9, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> While advancements in energy efficiency and reduced heating demand are a positive trend overall, they further build on the case made in this article that current projections for electric demand growth may not materialize as expected.</li>
</ul>
<p>These factors have affected European countries differently. Major economies such as France, Germany, and Spain experienced the steepest declines in demand, mostly due to decreasing industrial output. Electricity consumption in the region‚Äôs smaller eastern and northern economies responded more moderately to gas price increases, mainly because of their generally lower industrial demand and dependency on gas.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cc537d20-c313-4157-b270-0b715640ae28"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cc537d20-c313-4157-b270-0b715640ae28" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚ÄúMap of day ahead prices,‚Äù ENTSOEe, September 2024; Sarah Brown and Dave Jones, <em>European electricity review 2024</em>, Ember, February 7, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="Aerial close up of modern house with solar array reflecting golden hour sunlight." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/energy%20and%20materials/our%20insights/global%20energy%20perspective%202024/thumb-gep-getty-2149800808-1536x1536.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Global Energy Perspective 2024</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/energy-and-materials/our-insights/global-energy-perspective" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Read the report</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<h2>Uncertainty spans multiple sectors</h2>
<p>To explore electricity demand predictions in more detail, we examined the power demand forecast in McKinsey‚Äôs <em>Global Energy Perspective 2024</em> (Continued Momentum scenario), identifying key areas where demand growth is at risk.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="783f98ce-4080-4f10-8772-0a46de62c04a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="783f98ce-4080-4f10-8772-0a46de62c04a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em><a href="/industries/energy-and-materials/our-insights/global-energy-perspective">Global Energy Perspective 2024</a></em>, September 17, 2024; this analysis is not a consistent scenario but rather an assessment of individual risks within each sector.</span></span></span></a></span> While approximately 460 terawatt-hours (TWh) of additional demand is forecast by 2030, our analysis suggests that around 40 percent (180 TWh) of this might not materialize. Besides lower demand from industry, other key demand drivers, such as EVs and heat pumps, have grown at a slower pace than expected, too (Exhibit 3).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2e8fc41b-966c-47cb-bcbe-309427d35288"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2e8fc41b-966c-47cb-bcbe-309427d35288" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚Äú<a href="/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/our-insights/the-energy-transition-where-are-we-really">The energy transition</a>,‚Äù August 27, 2024; ‚ÄúEV sales H1 2024: Europe slowest growing region,‚Äù Rho Motion, July 12, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/electricity%20demand%20in%20europe%20growing%20or%20going/svgz-european-power-demand_ex3-v16.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Deployment of green technologies in Europe has slowed or decreased in several categories." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/electricity%20demand%20in%20europe%20growing%20or%20going/svgz-european-power-demand_ex3-v16.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>The uncertain outlook spans several sectors, including buildings, transport, industry, green hydrogen, and data centers (Exhibit 4). Sectors most affected by high prices would likely include those where the total cost of ownership (TCO) is a significant factor when electrifying, such as EVs and residential heating, as well as high-investment or technically challenging areas, such as high-temperature industrial processes.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/electricity%20demand%20in%20europe%20growing%20or%20going/svgz-european-power-demand_ex4-v17.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="In Europe, up to 40 percent of the anticipated 460 terawatt-hour increase in electricity demand from 2023 to 2030 may not materialize." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/electricity%20demand%20in%20europe%20growing%20or%20going/svgz-european-power-demand_ex4-v17.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p><strong>Buildings:</strong> According to our analysis, annual heat pump sales in Europe decreased by 3 percent in 2023 to 2.9 million units, partly due to ongoing delays in supportive policy and partly driven by evolving business cases. More recently, several European heat pump manufacturers have reported sales declining by 47 percent in the first half of 2024, with full-year estimates reaching only 1.5 million heat pumps. This has led to permanent and temporary layoffs in the sector.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="907ca028-f310-4bc0-b492-1488c33e63d4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="907ca028-f310-4bc0-b492-1488c33e63d4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚ÄúNIBE Group gives notice of redundancy to 340 employees in Sweden,‚Äù NIBE, March 18, 2024; ‚ÄúHeat pump sales fall by 5% while EU delays action,‚Äù European Heat Pump Association, February 27, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> Given the direct tie between heat pumps and power demand, if the current rate of heat pump adoption continues, about 17 TWh of expected electricity demand could be at risk, putting electricity demand for heating 50 percent lower than expected in 2030.</p>
<p><strong>Transport:</strong> The growth in demand for battery electric vehicles (BEVs) and plug-in hybrids has decelerated over the past three years, dropping from a 42 percent year-on-year increase in 2021 to 21 percent in 2023. The picture looked even worse for the first half of 2024‚Äîonly a 1 percent increase in sales compared to the first half of 2023. High material costs, slow infrastructure development, and supply chain challenges could limit the total number of EVs to 36 million by 2030. The slowdown is partly due to reduced support schemes, though the introduction of more affordable models may revive momentum. If sales in Europe maintain their current pace, however, 45 percent of the anticipated EV-related power demand may not materialize, putting 58 TWh of road transport demand at risk by 2030.</p>
<p><strong>Industry:</strong> As reported in the press, industrial activity remains subdued, with high production costs and ongoing plant closures expected to extend into the fourth quarter of 2024.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7adf7a55-2108-4283-9116-f30a283727bc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7adf7a55-2108-4283-9116-f30a283727bc" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>The future of European competitiveness,</em> September 2024; ‚ÄúVolkswagen considers historic German plant closures,‚Äù Reuters, September 3, 2024; ‚ÄúBASF closes two more plants,‚Äù July 11, 2024; ‚ÄúVolkswagen considers German plant closures to save billions in costs,‚Äù The Guardian, September 2, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> Deindustrialization may continue as key players in vehicle manufacturing, steel, and chemical industries announce reductions in European production.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d7856c67-7b93-42ba-8c11-2aea70884f38"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d7856c67-7b93-42ba-8c11-2aea70884f38" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚ÄúVolkswagen considers historic German plant closures,‚Äù Reuters, September 3, 2024; ‚ÄúBASF closes two more plants,‚Äù July 11, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> Several companies have announced planned plant closures in recent years, citing unfavorable economic conditions in Europe.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="51fc699b-72c5-4a02-b0de-8fe26ea5a34d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="51fc699b-72c5-4a02-b0de-8fe26ea5a34d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Nel Weddle, ‚ÄúExxonMobil to close Gravenchon, France cracker and related derivative units in 2024,‚Äù Independent Commodity Intelligence Services, April 11, 2024; ‚ÄúSabic to begin Geleen cracker closure this week,‚Äù Argus, April 11, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> High energy prices and regulatory developments could drive further declines, potentially leading to a 10 percent reduction in steel and chemicals output by 2030. Of the sector‚Äôs expected growth, more than half‚Äî66 TWh‚Äîcould be at risk due to declining industrial output and slower electrification.</p>
<p><strong>Green hydrogen:</strong> Growth in power demand from green hydrogen is particularly uncertain, largely because of the limited confirmed offtake resulting from the high cost expectations for hydrogen. As a result, there have been delays in electrolyzer development, with many announced projects not reaching a final investment decision (FID).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="371b277d-11f4-4a4d-a660-2fca5dc8a17c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="371b277d-11f4-4a4d-a660-2fca5dc8a17c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚Äú<a href="/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/our-insights/the-energy-transition-where-are-we-really">The energy transition</a>,‚Äù August 27, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> Only 1.4 million tons per annum (Mtpa) of the low-carbon hydrogen pipeline has reached FID, compared to the 1.8 Mtpa forecast for 2030. This could result in a 20 percent lower electricity demand than expected for hydrogen production. In contrast, to meet 2030 targets, clean hydrogen (blue and green) production needs to increase approximately 25-fold in Europe over the next five years.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fb4adaa1-f9ea-40da-97bf-040d106dbd38"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fb4adaa1-f9ea-40da-97bf-040d106dbd38" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">‚Äú<a href="/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/our-insights/the-energy-transition-where-are-we-really">The energy transition</a>,‚Äù August 27, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p><strong>Data centers:</strong> Due to increasing workloads (such as enterprise apps and data storage), innovations in hardware, and data residency laws in the European Union, electricity demand from data centers is rising. However, it may be tempered by uncertainties related to AI-driven load increases, connection issues to already constrained grids, and new EU regulations. If the trends driving demand growth do not accelerate, 21 TWh could be at risk and could lead to overinvestment in potentially oversized assets.</p>
<h2>The possible implications of slower demand growth and how industry could adapt</h2>
<p>Lower-than-expected electricity demand growth in Europe could significantly impact overall system costs‚Äîand, ultimately, the path of the energy transition and Europe‚Äôs broader economic conditions. To mitigate these risks, it will be important for stakeholders across the energy value chain to monitor trends and adjust their strategies proactively in five key areas:</p>
<ol>
    <li><strong>Power generation assets:</strong> Planned total generation capacity and its composition will likely need to evolve in response to slower demand growth. Here, different scenarios are possible, including one in which Europe doubles down on sustainability and government targets and decides to invest further in energy transition generation assets and systems. However, overall system costs may rise as a result, posing fundamental challenges to affordability and resulting in supply and cost challenges impacting the future of European industry. To illustrate, roughly a 10 percent reduction in power demand could shift up to ‚Ç¨300 billion of investment in generation assets between 2025 and 2030 (30 percent of the expected total) to different sources. Even in that scenario, however, the required annual investments in the next five years would still be over 15 percent higher than they were in the last decade.</li>
    <li>
    <p><strong>Grid build-outs:</strong> Investments in T&D infrastructure may need to adapt to the future demand growth and the implications that develop regarding generation assets. For example, a reduction in power demand could translate to a shift in the size and shape of investment in T&D in the near-term 2025‚Äì30 period, although fundamentally, the total investment in the path to net zero is still likely to remain the same. We note that the required annual investments in the next five years would still be over 50 percent higher than they were in the past decade (and, in some geographies, still represent a two to five times scale-up of the build-out). System operators and local grids will need to adapt while still providing an essential utility.</p>
    <p>This may imply a change in focus, moving away from local build-outs and ever greater, more frequent, and larger interconnection and grid automation‚Äîall of which will have implications for grid fees. Innovative approaches like digitalization, microgrids, and energy storage could be explored to ensure cost-effective deployment.</p>
    </li>
    <li>
    <p><strong>Consumer impact and pricing:</strong> Lower electricity demand could lead to reduced wholesale power prices. While the lower landed costs of electricity may benefit consumers, they could possibly weaken the business case of power generation assets. If recouping the capital extended to connect those assets falls to wholesale prices only, customers could pick up the tab through higher power prices.</p>
    <p>In Germany, for example, household grid fees could increase from about 13 cents per kilowatt-hour (ct/kWh) in 2023 to about 18 ct/kWh in 2030 if demand aligns with government targets.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3f8f0e09-a1f2-4dca-8711-ce0e045a3463"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">20</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3f8f0e09-a1f2-4dca-8711-ce0e045a3463" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">All currency is in euros.</span></span></span></a></span> However, if a significant amount of this growth does not materialize, prices could increase to as much as 25 ct/kWh (of a total household power price of 51 ct/kWh), threatening affordability. A similar impact is expected for industrial rates, with implications for competitiveness.</p>
    </li>
    <li><strong>New market frameworks:</strong> The potential slowdown in demand growth could prompt renewed focus on new market frameworks to manage demand more effectively instead of merely increasing supply. Solutions could involve promoting energy efficiency, enhancing demand-side management, and investing in smart grids and energy storage. Overall, T&D system operators would be well advised to increase collaboration and better align investments to actual demand, leveraging long-term agreements to ensure value creation.</li>
    <li><strong>Potential positive impact on emissions:</strong> Of course, lower electricity demand could lead to a reduction in emissions in Europe, especially if it reduces the reliance on generation from fossil fuels, such as coal and gas. This could make it easier for countries to meet their climate targets, offering significant environmental benefits. However, this positive outlook is tempered by the realization that if lower industry emissions are linked to acquiring alternative or lower-cost energy, this could come from sources with higher emissions intensity than those in Europe, further depleting the global carbon allowance.</li>
</ol>
<hr>
<p>Despite expectations of continued growth in European electricity demand toward 2030, the current outlook suggests this could be as much as 40 percent lower than anticipated. Balancing sustainability goals with energy affordability and economic growth will require coordinated action between key players in the region.</p>
<p>Mitigating the impact of reduced power demand will require utilities, T&D companies, governments, and investors to realign their strategies with regularly updated demand forecasts. Enhanced grid flexibility will also be essential to maintain a stable and sustainable energy system. This need for increased agility will place strategic and organizational demands on both companies and regulators, ideally resulting in more robust systems for the future.</p>
<p>Above all, affected European players can closely monitor sector developments and key indicators, such as power retail prices, and start readying themselves now for a future that may not turn out quite as planned.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/alexander-weiss">Alexander Weiss</a></strong> is a senior partner in McKinsey‚Äôs Berlin office, <strong><a href="/our-people/diego-hernandez-diaz">Diego Hernandez Diaz</a></strong> is a partner in the Geneva office, <strong><a href="/our-people/tamara-gruenewald">Tamara Gr√ºenewald</a></strong> is an associate partner in the Zurich office, and <strong>Muthu Subbu</strong> is a consultant in the Amsterdam office.</p>

aria-atomic="true"></div></div><script id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Electricity demand in Europe going","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"a5e21ce3-8ccf-43e9-8fab-c6f857411583","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Electricity demand in Europe: Growing or going?"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"European power demand: Growing or going?"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"New analysis suggests that much of Europe\u0026rsquo;s anticipated electricity demand growth may not materialize, with important implications for the energy transition and industrial competitiveness."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"Much of the anticipated growth in European power demand may not materialize, with important implications for the energy transition and industrial competitiveness."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2024-10-24T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[audio 1]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRising uncertainty surrounding future electricity demand\u003c/strong\u003e could affect Europe\u0026rsquo;s energy transition and power infrastructure investment plans. Governments and system operators have projected that power demand in major European countries could increase by as much as 7 percent per year to 2030 after two decades of relative stagnation. In McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/energy-and-materials/our-insights/global-energy-perspective\"\u003eGlobal Energy Perspective 2024\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e report, the Continued Momentum scenario projects growth to be only slightly above 2 percent CAGR.[[footnote 1]] Further McKinsey analysis has found that up to 40 percent of this modeled growth may not, in fact, materialize. The possible impact of this reduced demand outlook might be profound if higher system costs drive up the price of electricity and potentially accelerate deindustrialization in the region.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eFactors, including elevated power prices, energy efficiency gains, and structural economic changes linked to deindustrialization, may all moderate the expected electricity demand growth. Mario Draghi\u0026rsquo;s recent report on the future of European competitiveness warns that the region faces a slow economic decline linked to deindustrialization.[[footnote 2]] Our analysis indicates that elevated power prices\u0026mdash;which are currently 60 to 90 euros per megawatt hour (EUR/MWh) across Europe versus historical averages of 30 to 50 EUR/MWh\u0026mdash;could increase industrial production costs and result in lower-than-expected power demand from the industrial sector (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Our analysis\u0026rdquo;). While reduced industrial demand is the primary contributing factor and focus of this article, shifts in overall industrial activity are, of course, a function of many interconnected factors, including macroeconomic conditions or demographic shifts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFollowing the major industrial shutdowns of 2022\u0026ndash;23, several big industrial players have more recently announced plans to move production to lower-cost locations.[[footnote 3]] Meanwhile, the uptake of other important electricity demand drivers, such as electric vehicles (EVs) and heat pumps, has slowed in the last three years, adding further questions about how European power demand could evolve in the years to 2030.[[footnote 4]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn this article, we examine the expected trajectory of electricity demand in Europe through 2030, the factors that may prevent this from fully materializing, and the broader implications for the region. We also touch on potential solutions such as revised market design, infrastructure build-out, demand-side response, and electrification incentives.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWhy electricity demand is expected to grow\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePower demand has long been expected to grow in Europe as increasing population and rising GDP drive higher overall energy consumption (despite efficiency gains). The current boom in AI could create a further demand surge, with data centers possibly accounting for as much as\n\u003ca href=\"/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/our-insights/the-role-of-power-in-unlocking-the-european-ai-revolution\"\u003e5 percent of total European power consumption by 2030\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[sidebar 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eMeanwhile, the energy transition has also spurred new transmission and distribution (T\u0026amp;D) investments to accommodate growing demand and the deployment of increasingly dispersed renewable energy sources (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;The evolving energy transition: McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s latest analysis\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe European Union\u0026rsquo;s commitment to achieving net zero by 2050 has led to increasingly ambitious policies concerning emissions, renewables, EVs, and heat pumps, all of which point to growing power demand. For example, the REPowerEU initiative aims to have at least 30 million newly installed heat pumps by 2030, up from 22 million in 2023, and the Renewable Energy Directive (RED III) has raised the 2030 target for renewable energy\u0026rsquo;s share of final consumption to 42.5 percent.[[footnote 5]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOther factors that could cause demand to grow include longer-term policies looking beyond 2030, regulations such as \u0026ldquo;Fit for 55,\u0026rdquo; the decreasing costs of electrification technology, and GDP recovery.[[footnote 6]] Taken together, these growth-signaling factors have led governments and system operators across major economies to forecast a 1 to 7 percent annual increase in electricity demand until 2030 (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003ch2\u003eFactors putting demand growth at risk\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAccording to our latest analysis, however, these growth expectations may not be attainable. In fact, electricity consumption in Europe has already slowed. Following steady growth of 1.4 percent per annum through the 2000s, peaking in 2008, demand growth has remained relatively muted. Since 2021, demand has dropped consistently at around 3 percent per annum, failing to meet expectations for a post-COVID-19 \u0026ldquo;bounce back\u0026rdquo; (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eHistorically, electricity demand was closely correlated with economic growth in most European economies\u0026mdash;over 2 percent GDP growth per annum between 2000 and 2008, a correlation of around 0.96 between electricity demand growth and GDP for that period.[[footnote 7]] But after the financial crisis and growth peak in 2008, GDP and electricity demand have delinked in these countries (with a correlation of approximately \u0026ndash;0.53).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are various underlying reasons for the decline in demand growth in recent years:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe COVID-19 pandemic and the invasion of Ukraine both impacted Europe\u0026rsquo;s power demand profile. The conflict in Ukraine triggered a gas shortage, with the resulting higher gas prices peaking at a yearly average of around $41 per metric million British thermal unit (MMBTU) in 2022\u0026mdash;up from a yearly average of $6/MMBTU in 2017 to 2019.[[footnote 8]] This, along with operational challenges at reduced-output nuclear plants in France and low hydroelectric production, caused many industrial companies to shut down across sectors such as steel, aluminum, and chemicals.[[footnote 9]] This deindustrialization trend has had a significant impact on power demand and is one of the key reasons why growth remains below historical levels.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe drop in power demand is also driven by considerable energy efficiency gains, structural economic changes\u0026mdash;such as offshoring and the transition to a more services-oriented economy\u0026mdash;and milder winters over the past couple of years that have reduced the demand for space heating.[[footnote 10]] While advancements in energy efficiency and reduced heating demand are a positive trend overall, they further build on the case made in this article that current projections for electric demand growth may not materialize as expected.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese factors have affected European countries differently. Major economies such as France, Germany, and Spain experienced the steepest declines in demand, mostly due to decreasing industrial output. Electricity consumption in the region\u0026rsquo;s smaller eastern and northern economies responded more moderately to gas price increases, mainly because of their generally lower industrial demand and dependency on gas.[[footnote 11]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[disruptor1up readnext]]\n\u003ch2\u003eUncertainty spans multiple sectors\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo explore electricity demand predictions in more detail, we examined the power demand forecast in McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s \u003cem\u003eGlobal Energy Perspective 2024\u003c/em\u003e (Continued Momentum scenario), identifying key areas where demand growth is at risk.[[footnote 12]] While approximately 460 terawatt-hours (TWh) of additional demand is forecast by 2030, our analysis suggests that around 40 percent (180 TWh) of this might not materialize. Besides lower demand from industry, other key demand drivers, such as EVs and heat pumps, have grown at a slower pace than expected, too (Exhibit 3).[[footnote 13]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe uncertain outlook spans several sectors, including buildings, transport, industry, green hydrogen, and data centers (Exhibit 4). Sectors most affected by high prices would likely include those where the total cost of ownership (TCO) is a significant factor when electrifying, such as EVs and residential heating, as well as high-investment or technically challenging areas, such as high-temperature industrial processes.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBuildings:\u003c/strong\u003e According to our analysis, annual heat pump sales in Europe decreased by 3 percent in 2023 to 2.9 million units, partly due to ongoing delays in supportive policy and partly driven by evolving business cases. More recently, several European heat pump manufacturers have reported sales declining by 47 percent in the first half of 2024, with full-year estimates reaching only 1.5 million heat pumps. This has led to permanent and temporary layoffs in the sector.[[footnote 14]] Given the direct tie between heat pumps and power demand, if the current rate of heat pump adoption continues, about 17 TWh of expected electricity demand could be at risk, putting electricity demand for heating 50 percent lower than expected in 2030.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTransport:\u003c/strong\u003e The growth in demand for battery electric vehicles (BEVs) and plug-in hybrids has decelerated over the past three years, dropping from a 42 percent year-on-year increase in 2021 to 21 percent in 2023. The picture looked even worse for the first half of 2024\u0026mdash;only a 1 percent increase in sales compared to the first half of 2023. High material costs, slow infrastructure development, and supply chain challenges could limit the total number of EVs to 36 million by 2030. The slowdown is partly due to reduced support schemes, though the introduction of more affordable models may revive momentum. If sales in Europe maintain their current pace, however, 45 percent of the anticipated EV-related power demand may not materialize, putting 58 TWh of road transport demand at risk by 2030.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIndustry:\u003c/strong\u003e As reported in the press, industrial activity remains subdued, with high production costs and ongoing plant closures expected to extend into the fourth quarter of 2024.[[footnote 15]] Deindustrialization may continue as key players in vehicle manufacturing, steel, and chemical industries announce reductions in European production.[[footnote 16]] Several companies have announced planned plant closures in recent years, citing unfavorable economic conditions in Europe.[[footnote 17]] High energy prices and regulatory developments could drive further declines, potentially leading to a 10 percent reduction in steel and chemicals output by 2030. Of the sector\u0026rsquo;s expected growth, more than half\u0026mdash;66 TWh\u0026mdash;could be at risk due to declining industrial output and slower electrification.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGreen hydrogen:\u003c/strong\u003e Growth in power demand from green hydrogen is particularly uncertain, largely because of the limited confirmed offtake resulting from the high cost expectations for hydrogen. As a result, there have been delays in electrolyzer development, with many announced projects not reaching a final investment decision (FID).[[footnote 18]] Only 1.4 million tons per annum (Mtpa) of the low-carbon hydrogen pipeline has reached FID, compared to the 1.8 Mtpa forecast for 2030. This could result in a 20 percent lower electricity demand than expected for hydrogen production. In contrast, to meet 2030 targets, clean hydrogen (blue and green) production needs to increase approximately 25-fold in Europe over the next five years.[[footnote 19]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eData centers:\u003c/strong\u003e Due to increasing workloads (such as enterprise apps and data storage), innovations in hardware, and data residency laws in the European Union, electricity demand from data centers is rising. However, it may be tempered by uncertainties related to AI-driven load increases, connection issues to already constrained grids, and new EU regulations. If the trends driving demand growth do not accelerate, 21 TWh could be at risk and could lead to overinvestment in potentially oversized assets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe possible implications of slower demand growth and how industry could adapt\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLower-than-expected electricity demand growth in Europe could significantly impact overall system costs\u0026mdash;and, ultimately, the path of the energy transition and Europe\u0026rsquo;s broader economic conditions. To mitigate these risks, it will be important for stakeholders across the energy value chain to monitor trends and adjust their strategies proactively in five key areas:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePower generation assets:\u003c/strong\u003e Planned total generation capacity and its composition will likely need to evolve in response to slower demand growth. Here, different scenarios are possible, including one in which Europe doubles down on sustainability and government targets and decides to invest further in energy transition generation assets and systems. However, overall system costs may rise as a result, posing fundamental challenges to affordability and resulting in supply and cost challenges impacting the future of European industry. To illustrate, roughly a 10 percent reduction in power demand could shift up to \u0026euro;300 billion of investment in generation assets between 2025 and 2030 (30 percent of the expected total) to different sources. Even in that scenario, however, the required annual investments in the next five years would still be over 15 percent higher than they were in the last decade.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGrid build-outs:\u003c/strong\u003e Investments in T\u0026amp;D infrastructure may need to adapt to the future demand growth and the implications that develop regarding generation assets. For example, a reduction in power demand could translate to a shift in the size and shape of investment in T\u0026amp;D in the near-term 2025\u0026ndash;30 period, although fundamentally, the total investment in the path to net zero is still likely to remain the same. We note that the required annual investments in the next five years would still be over 50 percent higher than they were in the past decade (and, in some geographies, still represent a two to five times scale-up of the build-out). System operators and local grids will need to adapt while still providing an essential utility.\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eThis may imply a change in focus, moving away from local build-outs and ever greater, more frequent, and larger interconnection and grid automation\u0026mdash;all of which will have implications for grid fees. Innovative approaches like digitalization, microgrids, and energy storage could be explored to ensure cost-effective deployment.\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eConsumer impact and pricing:\u003c/strong\u003e Lower electricity demand could lead to reduced wholesale power prices. While the lower landed costs of electricity may benefit consumers, they could possibly weaken the business case of power generation assets. If recouping the capital extended to connect those assets falls to wholesale prices only, customers could pick up the tab through higher power prices.\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eIn Germany, for example, household grid fees could increase from about 13 cents per kilowatt-hour (ct/kWh) in 2023 to about 18 ct/kWh in 2030 if demand aligns with government targets.[[footnote 20]] However, if a significant amount of this growth does not materialize, prices could increase to as much as 25 ct/kWh (of a total household power price of 51 ct/kWh), threatening affordability. A similar impact is expected for industrial rates, with implications for competitiveness.\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNew market frameworks:\u003c/strong\u003e The potential slowdown in demand growth could prompt renewed focus on new market frameworks to manage demand more effectively instead of merely increasing supply. Solutions could involve promoting energy efficiency, enhancing demand-side management, and investing in smart grids and energy storage. Overall, T\u0026amp;D system operators would be well advised to increase collaboration and better align investments to actual demand, leveraging long-term agreements to ensure value creation.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePotential positive impact on emissions:\u003c/strong\u003e Of course, lower electricity demand could lead to a reduction in emissions in Europe, especially if it reduces the reliance on generation from fossil fuels, such as coal and gas. This could make it easier for countries to meet their climate targets, offering significant environmental benefits. However, this positive outlook is tempered by the realization that if lower industry emissions are linked to acquiring alternative or lower-cost energy, this could come from sources with higher emissions intensity than those in Europe, further depleting the global carbon allowance.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDespite expectations of continued growth in European electricity demand toward 2030, the current outlook suggests this could be as much as 40 percent lower than anticipated. Balancing sustainability goals with energy affordability and economic growth will require coordinated action between key players in the region.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMitigating the impact of reduced power demand will require utilities, T\u0026amp;D companies, governments, and investors to realign their strategies with regularly updated demand forecasts. Enhanced grid flexibility will also be essential to maintain a stable and sustainable energy system. This need for increased agility will place strategic and organizational demands on both companies and regulators, ideally resulting in more robust systems for the future.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAbove all, affected European players can closely monitor sector developments and key indicators, such as power retail prices, and start readying themselves now for a future that may not turn out quite as
